Award.AwardTitle: Core Support for the Institute for Laboratory Animal Research
Award.AbstractNarration:
An award is made to the National Academy of Sciences to support the Institute for Laboratory Research (ILAR) to: 1) convene annual meetings of the ILAR Council advisory body; 2) support staff time to develop topics for new studies and projects and perform tasks related to completed studies; and 3) support staff time to produce the ILAR Journal.

The mission of Institute for Laboratory Animal Research (ILAR) is to evaluate and report on the scientific, technological, and ethical use of animals and related biological resources and of non-animal alternatives in non-food settings, such as research, testing, education, and production of pharmaceuticals. ILAR seeks to identify practices that provide for excellence in the welfare of animals used for these purposes, recognizing their moral value while achieving high-quality science. ILAR also evaluates and encourages the use, development, and validation of non-animal alternatives. By engaging the expertise residing in the laboratory animal science, veterinary, and broader biological research communities, ILAR formulates and disseminates guidelines and standards for humane and scientifically sound animal care and use and provides independent and objective advice on developments and key research opportunities in laboratory animal science and medicine to the U.S. federal government, the international biological research community, and the public. More information can be found at: http://dels.nas.edu/ilar/

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project "Core Support for the Institute of Laboratory Animal Research" provides funding to enable the Institute (ILAR) to continue to produce the kinds of significant results for the government, the scientific community, and the public discussed in this document. The mission of ILAR is to evaluate and report on the scientific, technological, and ethical use of animals in research, testing, education, and production of pharmaceuticals and chemicals. ILAR identifies science-based practices that provide for excellence in the welfare of research animals while achieving high-quality science and evaluates and encourages the development, validation, and use of non-animal alternatives. ILAR formulates and disseminates guidelines and standards for humane and scientifically sound animal care and use and provides independent and objective advice on developments and key research opportunities in research animal science and medicine to the U.S. federal government, the international biological research community, and the public.

The ILAR document, the Guide for the Care and Use of Laboratory Animals, is ILAR's most influential product. Through adoption by the National Institutes of Health (NIH) under the Health Research Extension Act of 1985, the Guide serves as the basis of the Public Health Service (PHS) regulations on animal care and use. All NIH funded animal research as well as that of many other federal agencies must follow the Guide, which carries the force of the law. The Guide is also used as a basis for accreditation by the Association for Assessment and Accreditation of Laboratory Animal Care (AAALAC) International, which provides accreditation to laboratory animal care and use facilities worldwide.

Other ILAR reports have also made substantive contributions to the advancement of biological research, the improvement of laboratory animal science and medicine, and the welfare of laboratory animals. For instance, Psychological Well Being of Nonhuman Primates (1998) has been adopted as a standard reference by the Association of Primate Veterinarians, the American Society of Primatologists and AAALAC International. Other reports such as Recognition and Alleviation of Distress in Laboratory Animals (2008) and Recognition and Alleviation of Pain in Laboratory Animals (2009) are routinely used by Institutional Animal Care and Use Committees in reviewing protocols for animal research. And the report Scientific and Humane Issues in the Use of Random-Source Dogs and Cats in Research (2009), which recommended that NIH cease its practice of acquiring research animals from so-called "Class B dealers" who acquire and resell live dogs and cats to research institutions. The report found that there is no clear need to obtain those animals from Class B dealers and that the standard of care for animals in the possession of some Class B dealers requires an inordinate amount of government enforcement and is not commensurate with the policies of most government-funded research laboratories. NIH recently changed its policy on acquiring such random source animals in line with the report's recommendations. All of these reports are available for free download on the National Academies Press website at http://www.nap.edu/.

The ILAR Roundtable on Science and Welfare in Laboratory Animal Use provides a forum to foster communication and problem solving among the many constituencies with strong interests in the use of research animals. Roundtable members include representatives from the government, private corporations, professional societies, and academic institutions.
